title: Your Posts on X Are Being Used to Train Grok AI. Here's How to Stop it
description: Public tweets are fueling Elon's AI. Here's how to opt out of the data scraping.
content:
Elon Musk's X—or Twitter, as most of us still call it—has its own AI chatbot called Grok. In 2024, a change was made so that all your public tweets are now used to train the AI, whether you like it or not. But do you really want to be responsible for training an AI system that has routinely spouted racist and antisemitic rhetoric? I know I don't.

It's important to remember that all these tools are directly influenced by the people who make them, so it's not just Grok. But it just feels like I'm always hearing about how this specific AI is saying or doing something offensive because Elon wants to have his say in whatever public discourse is happening at the time. If you're still using X, but want no part in training Grok, here's how to make sure it's not using your data against your will.

According to this help page , X shares your public data with xAI, a Musk startup that acquired X earlier this year and is in charge of training and developing generative AI models, including Grok. That public data includes public posts, engagements, reposts, conversations on Spaces, and profile information, such as your bio and display name, along with any interactions you may have with Grok itself. This is all used to improve Grok's ability to understand requests, provide more accurate responses, and personalize its interactions with you.

The good news is that X offers several ways to control when your public data and interactions with Grok are used to train the company's AI systems. You can opt out of model training and Grok personalization, delete your conversation history with Grok, or make your account private.

To ensure my data wasn't being used to train Grok, I opened Settings and privacy > Privacy and safety > Grok & Third-party Collaborators and found three things enabled by default:

I unchecked all three. If you previously used Grok and now want nothing to do with it, click Delete conversation history and choose Delete again.

The other way to protect your tweets from Grok is to make your account private, since X doesn't use data from private accounts for its AI training.

Go back to Settings and privacy > Privacy and safety , but this time choose Audience, media and tagging . Enable Protect your posts, and only people who follow you can see your tweets. (Look for a lock icon next to your username to know it's protected.) Click the box next to Protect your videos , and any videos in your posts will not be downloadable by default.
summary: Elon Musk's X, or Twitter, has its own AI chatbot, Grok, which uses public data to train. The change was made in 2024, and users can now opt out of using their public data or make their account private. These data includes public posts, engagements, reposts, conversations on Spaces, and profile information. This data is used to improve Grok's ability to understand requests, provide accurate responses, and personalize its interactions with you. However, users may not wish to be responsible for training an AI system that has spouted racist and antisemitic rhetoric.
shortSummary: Elon Musk's X shares public data with Google's Grok, which can be used to train AI, but users can opt out and make their account private.
argos_summary: Elon Musk’s X platform now uses all public tweets to train its AI chatbot Grok, raising concerns about the spread of offensive content. Users can opt out of model training and personalization, delete their Grok conversation history, or make their account private to prevent their data from being used. X’s settings allow users to disable data sharing with xAI, the company behind Grok, and protect posts and videos from public view.
